English: the apples are sitting (there, on a table)
the apples are sitting on the table
my arm is shaking a lot
I carried it on my back
the birds are sitting in the tree
give me half the bread! (other order)
you can't do anything about it, that's how it is
Kashaya: heʔén ma baqʼo ci·cʼínʔkʰe tʰin e· mu, men é· mu

English: they're driving the car around too fast
carry it on your back! (alternate form)
the cat is sitting on the table
the cat is climbing around in the tree
close it! (door); turn it off! (faucet, machine)
I was washing clothes and got really tired
come and eat some food! (to several)
the dog is barking a lot
the dog is bothering the children
Kashaya: hayu ʔém naṭá yya ʔel ʔama dúhqʰawa·du

English: the dog is always bothering the children
Kashaya: hayu ʔém naṭá yya ʔel duhqʰawá·duce·du

English: the dog looks like it's laughing
Kashaya: hayu ʔem cʰuwayá·du min pʰiʔtʼawam ˇ

English: the dog is wagging its tail
they've gone away, left (I saw it)
they've already gone away, left (I saw it)
they've already gone far away (I saw it)
he can run faster than she can
he knows more than I do
I hear you but I don't understand
Kashaya: šocé· ʔa mito muʔnatí baʔyahtʰelá· ʔa
ma·dáʔkʰe pe·su buhqʰal e· mu ˇ

English: he's running faster than she is
have the horse carry it on its back!
the horse is (evidently) carrying the deer on its back
how would you say it in Indian?
Kashaya: heʔén ṭa ma mice·duʔba ʔacaʔ ta·wi

English: I want a little acorn mush
if you don't know how, try!

Kashaya: ʔa· ṭ’o ṭa q’oʔdi ʔém, ma ṭ’o heʔén ʔwa

English: I'm full; I've had enough to eat (or drink)
I'm full; I've had enough to eat (or drink) (2)
isn't he tall! how tall he is!
it's not like that; it didn't happen

Kashaya: yá·we miʔkʰe ʔóʔ ma dinʔwade· ˇ
yá·we miʔkʰe ma ʔóʔ dinʔwade· ˇ

English: he/she has gone away, left (they say)
he/she has already gone away, left (they say)
maybe they left each other for a little while
they (a family) have been separated for a while
the man and woman got divorced
give it to me! (serving food or drink)
have the horse carry my deer on its back!
Kashaya: kʰe bihše ʔel kawa·yu ʔél pʰeyicʼqa

English: I carried the deer on my back

Kashaya: kʰe qáhca ʔe hni mu ˇ

English: my name is Inez (responding to a question)
the weather turned bad, overcast on us
the pain is small; it aches a little
the person is walking around naked
pick up the (bag of) potatoes and put them on the table!
pull it apart! tear it in half!
brush yourself off with a brush!
sit down (on the ground) in one group!
sit down (on the ground) in several groups!
someone hit my car with mud
Kashaya: ciba· tʰin maṭʼqʰa báneye· kʰe ma·kina

English: turn off the heat on the stove!
pick up that paper and put it on the table!
Kashaya: haʔal kalikákʰ dihcipʰi lamé·sa tol banemá
mu· miʔkʰe ʔáhca ʔe hni ˇ

English: the Indian way is very difficult
Kashaya: ʔaná· ʔahsiy e· mu ʔacaʔ ta·wi

English: the apples are sitting over there (on a table)
it's lying up there (on a shelf, roof)
it's lying over there (on a table or couch)
they saw us (responding to a question)

Kashaya: maʔu ṭʼo ma·dáʔkʰe cá·ška naṭa ʔ
maʔu kʰe qáhca ʔe hni ˇ

English: that's how it is, that's the way it is, it's like that
don't do that! don't do it!
the trees are standing in a group
I don't understand what you're saying
it (the car) is coming toward us; (person) is running toward us
the wagon is broken, broke down
I don't want to; I don't like it
he/she got well, made it, survived
what's (he, she) doing over and over?
Kashaya: baqʼó ʔwa ṭa mu kúʔmul cicʼi·dam ˇ

English: why are you pacing back and forth?
Kashaya: heʔén sʼin iwa ma qowálhqʰaʔ wanʔwadam ˇ

English: give (a bundle, several sticks of) wood!
bring (a bundle of) wood into the house!

Kashaya: hu· ˇ men sʼiyám ṭa ˇ
miʔkʰe ʔáhca ʔe hni mu ˇ
miʔkʰe ʔáhca ʔe hni maʔu ˇ
miʔkʰe ma ya·we ʔóʔ dinʔwade· ˇ
